name: Metrics, Monitoring & Alerting.txt - What are Metrics, Monitoring and Alerting?
description: This section explains that metrics are raw measurements or data points that represent the usage or behavior of resources within a system. These metrics can be low-level system metrics like CPU or memory usage, or higher-level application-specific metrics like requests per second or server pool membership. Some metrics are represented as a percentage of total capacity, while others are rates that indicate how busy a component is.
capabilities: Representing metrics as percentages of total capacity
Representing metrics as rates of activity

name: Metrics, Monitoring & Alerting.txt - Metrics
description: This section explains the concepts of metrics and monitoring in a system. Metrics are raw data points that provide insights into the behavior and health of a system, while monitoring is the process of collecting, aggregating, and analyzing these metrics to gain a holistic view of the system's performance, identify issues, and trigger automated responses. Metrics are the building blocks, and monitoring is the process of making sense of these metrics to understand trends, correlations, and changes in the system.
use_cases: Understanding historic trends in system performance
Correlating diverse factors affecting system behavior
Measuring changes in performance, resource consumption, or error rates
Automating responses based on specific metric values or patterns
capabilities: Collecting metrics from various sources (operating system, custom applications)
Storing and managing historical metric data
Aggregating and sampling older metric data
Initiating automated responses based on metric values

name: Metrics, Monitoring & Alerting.txt - Monitoring
description: This section explains the importance of monitoring systems in managing and analyzing metrics from various components of an application or infrastructure. It discusses how monitoring systems provide visualizations to help identify trends and understand the interactions between different components. Additionally, it highlights the ability of monitoring systems to correlate data from multiple sources, enabling administrators to recognize patterns and relationships between events across different resources. The section also introduces the monitoring tools used at Razorpay, including Amazon CloudWatch, Prometheus, StatusCake, and Sumologic, and briefly describes their functionalities.
use_cases: Visualizing metrics and trends for better understanding of system behavior
Correlating data from different sources to identify patterns and relationships between events
Defining and activating alerts based on specific conditions or thresholds
Monitoring external endpoints and website availability
